definition:
Let $k$ be a field, $V$ a vector space, $T:V\to V$ a linear
transformation, and $W$ a $T$-invariant subspace of $V$. Let $x \in V$.
The *$T$-conductor* of $x$ *in* $W$ is the set $S_T(x, W)$ containing
all polynomials $g \in k[X]$ such that $g(T)x \in W$. It happens to be
that this set is an ideal of the polynomial ring. We also use the term
$T$-conductor of $x$ in $W$ to refer to the generator of such ideal.

In the special case $W=\{0\}$, the $T$-conductor is called
*$T$-annihilator* of $x$. Another way to define the $T$-conductor of $x$
in $W$ is by saying that it is a monic polynomial $p$ of lowest degree
such that $p(T)x \in W$. Of course this polynomial happens to be unique.
So the $T$-annihilator of $x$ is the monic polynomial $m_x$ of lowest
degree such that $m_x(T)x = 0$.
